title: Uppy events fire multiple times [Solved]
body:
I use uppy in a next js page, where the user gets two dashboards : 
- Documents Upload : uppy = new Uppy({ id: "newListingDocuments" ) 
- Images Upload with uppy = new Uppy({ id: "newListingPhotos" ) 

I used a complete event for every instance : 
```
uppy.on("complete", async (result) => { 
 .......................
uppy.off('complete', ()=>console.log("complete for instance 1 is done"))
}
```
```
uppy.on("complete", async (result) => { 
 .......................
uppy.off('complete', ()=>console.log("complete for instance 2 is done"))
}
```

When a user uploads a file. The uppy on complete is executed multiple times even with uppy.off('complete', ...) 

I don't have this problem when i use one instance. 

Any solutions ? 

Context : i use the dashboard inside a multi page form controlled by formik for every field, except for the dashboards where the state is controlled by uppy !
author: younes-alouani

comments.body:
Solved : 
You need to call off() to remove previous handlers attached 

`uppy.off("complete", null).on("complete", anyFunctionHandler) `

I suggest this get mentionned in the documentation in the events section  :) !

I think you are looking for `uppy.once` method.

title: Docs note suggestion about Companion state
body:
Hi,
I just noticed an issue with my Companion server configuration, but did not go after in depth so I am not sure about the reasons. Anyways, I suggest at least updating the docs with the information below. I was running the server on Google Cloud Run, which automatically deploys multiple containers if the number of concurrent requests exceed the configured amount. It seems that Companion fails to make download requests if multiple containers are involved. There must be some kind of state which it expects to be available across all requests of a download batch (in this case, download batch means a group of images which are downloaded in the same queue). Download requests handled by the first container resolve correctly, for the rest, the WS connection is opened, but there are no messages at all.

title: file.size is incorrect if file is changed on disk after 'file-added' and before 'upload'
author: dkramerWiden

comments.body: That's right. The browser reads the file when you select it, not when it is uploaded. As far as I know, there is no way to do this differently. Reading a file from disk is impossible in the browser except through drag/drop and `<input type=file>`, which do not allow any control over timing. Browsers likely avoid re-reading files for privacy/security reasons.

```javascript
    uploadStarted: false
  },
  size: file.data.size || 'N/A',
  isRemote: isRemote,
  remote: file.remote || '',
  preview: file.preview
}
```
Would it be possible to pass function that would the file be ran trough to format it ? I currently have multiple upload sources and it makes it quite inconvenient to later display the files that are in state in tables and other components as they do not follow the same schema.
author: WhoAteDaCake

comments.body: Hi @WhoAteDaCake! Uppy depends on that specific structure internally, so we can't store it much differently. If you have a function that formats the structure you should be able to use that in your app when you are about to display the files though.
Closing this for now, feel free to comment or re-open if there‚Äôs something else we can do!

title: How to get files from request
body:
I use uppy.io in my Laravel project
I have string 
`uppy.use(Tus10, {endpoint: TUS_ENDPOINT, resume: true});`

Where `TUS_ENDPOINT = 'upload'`

And in controller action has `var_dump($_FILES)` 

But i get empty value

How it solve?
author: MirlanJA

comments.body: Hi, thanks for taking an interest. It seems you are not running a tus.io server, but are expecting apache/nginx to handle the file uploads and then have that webserver pass a reference to your php script in the global `$FILES` array, correct? That means you'll want to use the multipart plugin instead of the tus plugin. The tus plugin uses the tus.io protocol to enable resumable file uploads, but that requires running a tus server of some kind to receive the files.

title: Stricter typescript definitions
body:
The typescript definitions are a big help already, but on first sight they could be much stricter, and thus make development safer.

For example, the `Event`-type form `@uppy/core` resolves to 
`type Event = LiteralUnion<'file-added' | 'file-removed' | 'upload' | 'upload-progress' | 'upload-success' | 'complete' | 'error' | 'upload-error' | 'upload-retry' | 'info-visible' | 'info-hidden' | 'cancel-all' | 'restriction-failed' | 'reset-progress' | string & { };` which seems not quite ideal to me. This could to this exaggerated erroneous call to `uppy.on`: `uppy.on('upload-errrOOOoooOOOOOrrrr'`. Therefore I'd suggest to make these types stricter, and in the same run remove all the most of the `any`-types if possible
author: lwolle

comments.body: hi @lwolle, thanks for the suggestion. Stricter types are always a good idea and it's an ongoing effort. If there is anything in particular you'd like to quickly change, PRs are welcome :)

title: The transuppyloadit preset (yeah.. sorry)
body:
So we want to think about the interface of a function that bootstraps Uppy+Transloadit for newcommers so that they can be on their way with ~3 lines of JavaScript.

We haven't really figured out what the majority-usecase is for newcomers. Are they using react? Do they have an existing `<form>` file upload that they want to upgrade? Hard to answer. The point could be made that people well versed in React and the likes, will be the ones that have little problems sifting through the docs and will want to build and customize Uppy themselves, anyway (and they already can to a great degree). 

So to me, i think, it would be most valuable to cater to the other group of users, that is perhaps more novice but could enjoy fancy file uploaders nonetheless.

The idea rises that this group of people would be helped most with

- A ready to rock bundle with the transloadit & common plugins baked inside (should be hosted on the transloadit CDN)
- A clear cut example that has sane defaults baked in, and connects the tus/uppy-server/transloadit pieces for them
- Optionally, a way to transform the file input of an existing form into an uppy dashboard

Here's a first iteration just to kick things off, input very welcome

```js
transuppyloadit({
  target: '#myDiv'
  authKey: '123123123123',
}, function (encodedFiles) {
  // To add the URLs to the encoded files to your <form>
  $('form').append(`<input 
    type="hidden" 
    name="encodedFiles" 
    value="${JSON.stringify(encodedFiles)}"
  />`)
})
```
